WEIRD DREAMS

Chapter One

Day broke over Plymouth, bringing a slow grey sky, damp morose streets and damp morose milkmen, finished off by a minor surge in the electricity supply as quarter of a million clock radios turned on to the early morning show.

Waking up is hard to do, thought Steve. Radio playing, birds singing, Monday morning. He sighed, turned over, and without opening his eyes hit the radio right on the snooze button. That'd teach it. Another five minutes wouldn't hurt...

But radios are made of sterner stuff. Five minutes later, unbowed by such early morning violence, it resumed its unspeakable pop. Which turned, in time, unto unpalatable news. Yawn... He really should get up now, or he'd have to run for the bus again. Strange - his usual warm sleepiness was mixed with something else...

Two records after the news. He really had to get up now. Least disgusting pair of boxer shorts, that shirt would do for today, and into the bathroom to shave his teeth... breakfast, paper and irresponsible TV weathermen later, Steve had diagnosed his problem.

He was feeling a bit peaky, as his mum would've said had she not been living in North Dakota. Nothing worse than that. Still, Steve mused, perhaps he was coming down with the flu. Perhaps he ought to get something for it. To really get Monday going, among the junk mail was a note from his dentist reminding him of his six-monthly checkup. Which was, he noticed, tomorrow. Super.

He ran for the bus, went upstairs and he read the paper, then trudged the ten minute walk from stop to work. Wet pavements and grey skies - it wasn't actually raining, but that was only a matter of time - did nothing to remove his malaise. In the office, he mentioned his lack of well-being to Emily, a bright girl in the postroom he'd got his eye on. He had often wondered whether he should ask her out but, just as often, decided not to. Never know, keep the friendship going and who knows what might happen? He'd never noticed, which was a bit insensitive on his part, that Emily was bored with life. More importantly, and this really wasn't his fault, he'd never noticed that she was a bored daemon. One of those mythical creatures who spend their eternal lives pushing misery, evil and discord.

Emily hadn't started out as a daemon, few people do; her body had been possessed by the spirit Zelloripus as she waited out her punishment. Three thousand years ago, Zelloripus had been banished from the Central Circle of the court of Asklarioum in Chael for a crime against fellow daemons. A crime so despicable that, had it worked, she would have challenged the Great One herself.

Given human form and stripped of many of her daemonic powers, she was sent to live the life of a mortal being on one of the less pleasant planets, Earth. As each host body died, she hopped into a new one, taking over the mind and feeding on the soul. Three thousand years into her sentence, with three thousand more to go, she was not happy. Sixty centuries in Plymouth is enough to embitter anyone. Even one whose residual evilness could, if focussed, melt a toddler's ice cream from a distance of ten miles.

Today there were many puddles of Guiseppi's Famous Italian Ice Cream on the pavements of Plymouth. For today was special. Exactly half-way through Zelloripus' exile, she was feeling mean and ornery and disposed to high mischief. She despised the humans whose form she took; they by and large achieved oblivion in just seventy short years. She especially despised Steve, whose somnolent form sonorously snoring through lunchbreaks was a continual reminder of a contented peace of mind denied her.

Daemons don't sleep; chances are that Another lurks nearby with designs on their soulstuff. A diabolic doze is the best they can normally manage; even this is denied those cast out of Hades because of the forces of Good that are on constant watch. Even, it had to be said, in Plymouth, where three thousand years of sleepless nights and boring days were driving Zelloripus close to breaking point. So far, she'd stuck to the rules, because using what remained of her powers to tamper with mortal affairs could double or treble her stay on Earth. But only if she was detected; the temptation to lash out at something or someone was growing. Her current job, with Plymouth's third most succesfful producer of soap, was not helping things.

So mere bad timing could explain Steve's unhappy encounter with Zelloripus, or Emily as she should be called, on this day in particular. Maybe it was just bad luck that accounted for the copious yawns, heavy eyelids and sleep-slurred voice with which he laced the conversation over her franking machine. But the following conversation was almost too bad to be true...

"Hiya Emily," said Steve. "You're looking wide eyed for a Monday morning. Wish I could be so awake, but I've been in bed most of the weekend."

"Poor soul." said Emily, "What's the matter?"

"Oh, I dunno. Think it's a touch of the flu; all I can do is sleep. It was a real effort to get up today. You don't know of anything that could perk me up a bit, do you?"

Emily, bitter from boredom, was close to the edge. "No," she said "I don't usually get that sort of problem. With sleeping, I mean."

It was probably his attempt at humour, or maybe it was a particularly clumsy chat-up line, that did it. "Perhaps you should sleep with me - it would maybe rub off a little. There's nothing like a good night's kip to make your fellow man seem a bit nicer..."

"I'm sure" said Emily with a smile so sharp it was opening the letters, "that you're right there. Tell me, Steve, do you dream?"

"Dream? No, can't say that I do. Not that I remember, that is. But if I did, it would be of you."

"How sweet. Perhaps I can help you, at least" and here the smile was diamond-tipped "with the flu. I think I might just have something in my handbag. Hold on, let me go and get it."

Steve was pleased. It might be worth asking her out after all, let's see, there's the funfair out of town... no, she's too bright for that... Outside, the weak sunlight darkened for a moment, as if a cloud had passed.

She came back. "Here we are, something I got from a drug store last time I had the flu." It was a small brown bottle, with an indistinct label and, just visible in the powdery interior, three white pills. "You're supposed to have them before a meal, just take the lot tonight with a bottle of red wine and some cheese and you'll be a new man."

"Thanks very much, Emily" said Steve, taking the bottle from her hand. "I'll do that. Look, what are you doing this weekend? Do you fancy a trip to see the new Stallone film or something?"
"I'm not sure" lied the being with three thousand years' worth of identical Plymothian weekends stretched out in front of her. "Let's see how you're feeling in a couple of days. Wouldn't want to over-exert you during your convalescence".

"Oh, I'm sure I'll be fine. I don't think I'll change my mind!"

"We'll see" said Emily, allowing just a hint of cold, evil-tinged boredom to slip out.

That evening, Steve wondered about Emily's last words. There was something not quite right, he decided, and came to a similar conclusion about the thrice-microwaved chilli con carne sitting in a bowl in the fridge. Then he remembered that wine and cheese had been recommended, and, although he was feeling fine by now, he thought that taking the lady's medicine followed by a triumphal Tuesday morning could do no harm. He had the cheese, and trotted out to the nearest 7-11 to get a bottle of red wine.

Back at home, he emptied the three pills out of the bottle into his hand. Nothing special, thought he, and with a flourish popped them into his mouth and washed them down with a long draft of Burgundy. The cheese sandwich followed. A quick scan of the TV pages - why is there never anything on a Monday night? - convinced him of the desirability of bed.

It's not generally appreciated that much magic is real, test-tubed and white-coated, science. Merlin's laboratory technique would have brought murmurs of approval from Pasteur, and watching Shiva smite (from a safe distance) might well have enlightened Einstein still further. It's just that while the great unwashed mass of men were more interested in squabbling, sex and smallpox it contented the Immortals to hide their rational prowess behind a web of mystic mishmash.

Sure, there is magic to be had, but using it brings many repercussions which might not be completely controllable. Many magicians had lost their souls in the long research programme which, although almost half as old as the Universe, was still not producing results. But boy, was it over budget. Some of its more spectacular failures were still puzzling astronomers from a thousand worlds; more than few of whom were unexpected by-products from an experiment or two themselves.

Emily was especially wary of employing the Dark Art. Not only had it landed her in this mess in the first place, but its use could signal loud and clear her position to any number of undesirable companions from the busybodies at Asklarioum, or something far more sinister. As it was, materialising the pills had been risky enough. Her excellent knowledge of human biochemistry helped her from there.

As Steve dropped off to sleep, the pills were lying inert in his stomach. Slowly the gastric acid ate away the outer case, and the compounds within began to diffuse out. And what compounds, the like of which had not been seen on Earth before or (it is safe to assume) since. Any chemist worth his NaCl would have given his spatula to have been in on the action.

First, the long chain molecules from the cheese were broken down to several interesting substances. The alcohol from the wine helped carry these and others from the pills themselves to the stomach wall, through which they slipped like Mexicans into Texas. On the other side of the wall, the usual gang of enzymes were waiting to digest the evening meal; but they weren't ready for what came at them. The scene of chemical carnage was brutal but short.

Past the first stage of digestion, the intruding substances reached the blood stream. Dissolved in the plasma, they drifted up until they got to Steve's brain. The blood brain barrier - that wonderful filter that keeps hunks of pizza molecule out while letting oxygen in - was as effective as a traffic cop against a battalion of Soviet tanks. Emily's dark designs began their invidious work.

Steve's brain was defenceless against the chemical onslaught. The vast, and mostly unused, network of neurones lay in front of them. Even as the last molecules were arriving, the compounds got to work. They diddled the dopamine receptors, they speeded up the cortical synapses, they nobbled the noradrenaline. A thin web of complex bonds spread deep into Steve's cerebellum, like frost over a tree. Further and further they went, until every part of his brain was invaded and controlled. For the moment they did nothing, but somewhere else in the Plymothian night a small chuckle of anticipation bounced off the flock wallpaper. In his sleep, Steve stirred and shivered.

Chapter 2

The next day, Steve woke up, as usual, to the clock radio. Unusually, he found himself listening to it, and, even more strangely, it annoyed him. He turned over in bed and thumped the switch, leaving the bedroom to the birds, noisy Fords and myriad other sounds of morning. He stared at the ceiling. Hangover? No, he'd only had a couple of glasses of wine last night. Anyway, his head didn't hurt and he felt all right, sort of, except... He was wide awake. That was odd, too, as most days he only started to really wake up on the bus into work.

He glanced at the clock radio; he still had a good half-hour until he had to leave, so he tried to doze. As he closed his eyes, the world spun. About fifteen years ago, he'd gone to Scotland with his parents, and once he'd crawled up to the edge of a granite cliff and peered over at the rocks and sea hundreds of feet beneath. He remembered amazement, awe and no little fear, but most of all he remembered the spiralling vertigo. That was what he was feeling now - he gripped the sides of the bed and opened his eyes rapidly, sweating.

The flu? Those pills he took last night? Could be, but he'd never been ill like that before, nor taken anything from a chemist that shook him up so badly. For a moment he was worried, but then the morning took over again, and the sound of a bus pulling up the hill reminded and reassured him that another normal day was waiting. He got out of bed and, standing up, felt fine once more. The coffee and eggs of breakfast tasted really good, but he didn't feel like reading his paper on the bus. For some reason, he wasn't interested in "Rock Star Eats Own Hand, Sells Guitar", which seemed to be the most earthshaking intelligence on offer. Back in the office, he homed in on Emily.

"Hey, Emily" he said "Those pills seemed to have done the trick. No flu, not a sniffle. I'm feeling really awake. They're good stuff - what're they called? I'd like to get some, just for next time, you know?"

She giggled, a short, high-pitched stutter like a pony neighing. "Glad they seem to have worked, Steve. I can't remember their name, though, I've had them for a while. Still, if it comes back to me I'll let you know."

"You've usually got such a good memory, Emily" said Steve ingratiatingly. "Me, mine's like a sieve. Can't even remember things like buying milk or doctor's appointments. Oh no!"

"What's up?" asked Emily, wondering for a moment whether she'd miscalculated something and wondering, just for a moment, what exactly she'd done. Just for a moment, and then she realised. "Forgotten an appointment?"

"Dentist. What's the time? Look, I've got to rush. See you at lunch - if I've got any teeth left" And he dashed into the boss' office to explain his impending absence.

He rushed out of the building. His dentist was about a half a mile away, and by walking fast he could make it. Past the bombed church in the roundabout, past the police station, up the hill, past the library, past the reservoir and into Dr V. Sells, known since childhood as Dr Weasel. The receptionist looked through her window - hello <PRESIDIO_ANONYMIZED_PERSON>, hello Mr Trevathen take a seat he's running a little late - and he dived into the piles of House and Garden from 1972.

Back in the office, the morning post had been sorted and distributed, and there was, as usual, half-an-hour's hiatus before the pre-lunch mailbags came in. Jill went out to round up all the outgoing mail from the seven floors, leaving Emily to herself. She checked her watch, and felt the sea of infinite boredom recede a little. Any minute now, and the first part of her plan would start to work.

Deep within Steve's brain, profound changes were taking place. The tendrils of diabolic chemistry insinuated into his hippocampus, a small lump of grey matter normally concerned with sorting Steve's experience (such as they were) into long-term recall, and started to subtly rewire his memory mechanisms. Large portions of his mind were converted into the biological equivalent of RAM; ready to record experiences and, having recorded them, control his mind as a program controls a computer's processor. Elsewhere similar changes were taking place, but for now things were ready just to record. Just for now.

The triggers to load the program were complex. If Steve was interested, then whatever it was that held his interest would be sorted, stored, activated. If he was frightened, amused, intrigued, it would all be recorded. But for this to work, he had to be capable of taking an interest in the first place. So part of Emily's chemical mishmash sharpened his wits, heightened his awareness, upped his IQ to just short of genius. This, she thought, was a nice move. Not only did it ensure that the data recorded would be powerful and particularly apt, but when the second stage began he would be only too capable of, mmmm, appreciating what was happening to him. He might even fight back, which would round off the whole thing nicely. And, she though with a daemonic delight, it would serve him right to be given a glimpse of what it's like to have an intelligence confronted with infinite boredom.

Steve was, as the plan demanded, unaware of the mental mayhem crystallising beneath his cranium. But he was getting painfully aware of a lot of other things as he sat in the formica and chipboard waiting room. The posters of rabbits noshing carrots and jaunty poems about plaque ("Clean Clean Clean your teeth! Or else the germs get underneath!") were fading and a couple flapped loose at the corners. They'd been there since he'd started seeing Dr Weasel, and, he mused, the place probably hadn't seen a touch of paint for ten years before that.

The bright orange and grey polypropelene bucket chairs finished of a fine example of early 'sixties public health design. Now why did he think that? He'd been here every six months for years, and usually only worried about whether he'd get a filling or not. Those old magazines - did people really think that the ideal home looked like that? The clothes they wore in the photos looked laughable too, but he could remember when he'd thought they looked good. How strange... perhaps the jacket and jeans he was wearing now would be equally ridiculous in ten years time.

The buzzer chainsawed its way into his daydreams, and the receptionist looked up. "Mr Trevathen?". He stood up, and went into the surgery. Dr Sells was shuffling through some papers at a desk, and the Chair sat in the middle of the room beneath the usual battery of technology.

"Hello Steve", said the dentist. "Sit down please. Now then, any problems since last time? It's good to see you keeping these checkups. Some people just don't bother after they leave home, and when something goes wrong there are all sorts of things to put right. How's your mother, by the way? It was America she moved to, wasn't it?"

As usual, Steve had to wait for three or four questions to go past before he could get a word in. "Yes, she's settled down in North Dakota and she's doing fine. I might go over to see her at Christmas. My teeth are OK, too, but I wouldn't want to miss anything that needs looking at."

"A fine attitude. Now then, lie down and open up."

Steve looked up at the light. "That's new, isn't it? The old one was a different colour."

"That's right, very observant! This one's a new low-voltage design, much more reliable and brighter too. I don't think anyone else has noticed. Open wide."

The nurse hooked in some suction, and went to get Steve's notes.

"Three's OK, two's OK, one's OK, one's OK, two's OK, three's OK, filling on four's a little bitty; we'll sort that out..."

Dr Sells continued chanting his litany as Steve noticed, for the first time it seemed, the antiseptic smell, the faint noise of the machinery behind the dentist, the charts on the wall and the rows of dentures on the shelves. He felt the faint scratching inside his head as the dentist probed away. As Steve had forgotten about the appointment, he hadn't given his teeth the customary vigourous pre-checkup brushing and this was apparently noticeable.

"Hello, we haven't been very thorough with your brushing, have we?" Typical quack, though Steve, lapsing into patronising parental tones. Doctor knows best. "Well, there's a cavity just starting on one of your premolars, and a slightly messy filling to tidy up. We'll have a poke around and fix them."

Steve had collected a lot of fillings from a chocolate childhood, and had the memories to match. As various instruments of torture were produced and whined, sucked and scrunched their way around his mouth, he remembered the old fears with a vividness that surprised him. He winced as the drill scoured the cavity, and was very relieved at the instruction to rinse and spit. Strange taste, this pink liquid.

"While I was fixing those teeth, Steve, I spotted something that might be serious. I'd better have a look at it."

This was new. He opened his mouth obediently, and became more apprehensive as Dr Sell's usual banter failed to intersperse his dental deliberations. Finally the dentist stood up, and Steve closed his mouth.

"One of your molars is misplaced - I don't know why I didn't catch it before, but there you go. Normally I'd leave it, as it's been there for years without causing any problems, but there are signs that you've got some more teeth coming through underneath."

"Eh? You mean I'm teething?"

"No, not quite. It's not uncommon for some people to have a third set of teeth at some time during their lives, and you might be one of them. In any case, I should really get that molar out otherwise it could be very bad for your jaw. It's not really fair that you should have to have a tooth pulled, since you're one of my better patients, but it's a good thing I caught it. Gas or needle?"

He means it, Steve thought. He hadn't had a tooth out before, and the prospect frightened him. Adrenalin started to seep into his blood stream. His heart speeded up, but in his brain the new mechanisms fired up and channelled the stream of his senses into the almost infinite capacity of the revamped memory.

"Oh, gas I think. Is it dangerous?"

"No, not very." Oh, how reassuring, what soothing Weasel words.

"Is the needle safer?"

"There's nothing to worry about with either method. But the gas hurts less."

"Fine. Will it take long?"

"About half an hour, and you should be OK within the hour. Not driving, are you?"

"I walked here."

"No problems then. You might find things a bit fuzzy for a while, but it wears off."

Steve remembered something Emily had said, and for the first time felt sadness for a thing which had never happened.

"Will I dream?"

"Hard to day. Some people do, but most don't."

The nurse had been tinkering with a mess of tubes and cylinders, and brought it to the side of the Chair. While she prepared a tray of gleaming steel instruments, some of which Steve thought would look more in keeping in his local garage, Dr Sells continued his spiel.

"Now then, I'll want you to breath deeply from the mask while counting to ten. You won't get past about seven, but you won't notice that. Ready, Sandra?"

The nurse passed over a facemask, which the dentist placed over Steve's mouth.

"Righty-ho - start breathing and counting. Sweet dreams!"

Here we go, then. One... suck... two... blow... three... suck... four... blow... hmmm, this is quite pleasant... where was I... teeth...

In the surgery, the dentist checked Steve's pulse, eyes and respiration. Satisifed that his patient was well under, he gave him a few seconds more and started to prepare for oral excavation.

Back at the office, Jill wanted to know what Emily was finding so funny. Emily merely giggled, and carried on sorting the post. All that day, she'd be in high spirits, surprising those who were used to her normal sarcastic mood. To those who asked why, she'd reply only that 'Life's a gas, isn't it?'

Chapter 3

Teeth... five... jive.. on the third stroke... hey, why aren't I under yet? Better warn the Weasel not to start pulling just yet. Steve opened his eyes.

If this is dreaming, thought Steve, I haven't missed much. The view reminded him of Dartmoor, where he used to spend the school holidays camping and walking. Only this place was flat for miles, with no inviting tors to clamber up or run down. Behind him the plain stretched out as far as he could see, so for want of anything better to do he started to walk towards the mountains. After a few minutes, he looked as his watch. Or he tried to, but on raising his arm all he saw was a bare wrist. He was greatly troubled. It wasn't so much the lack of a watch that bothered him, nor the fact that the rest of his body was, on inspection, entirely bare, but the troublesome actuality that the body in question wasn't the same one he'd grown up in. In fact, it was borderline as to whether it was Homo Sapiens or not, what with the long hair on the legs and the excessive number of flattened toes. The blue colour didn't help either.

For some reason, he calmed down. Out of curiosity, he tried to yell out "Anyone there?" and was intrigued by the guttural explosion that forced its way out of his mouth, past his fangs and into the leaden air. Fangs. Hmmm. That would startle the good Doctor. He realised with some surprise that he must still be in the Chair, with Dr Sells tapping away like a sculptor producing a miniature statue out of a chip of marble.

He was vaguely uncomfortable about the fact that he'd forgotten so easily who he really was, and tried to shut his eyes to block out the flat dullness of wherever he was. And was gripped by the vertigo as he had been back in his bedroom. This time he got the impression of falling down a well by starlight; a fast fading sprinkling of light and the infinite void waiting...

The landscape looked much more inviting after that. If this was a gas-induced dream he'd sit it out. Half an hour wasn't so long. But it felt like much more than that by the time he decided to get up and explore some more. Maybe his sense of time had gone the way of his skin colour. And, for that matter, the rest of his body, which had acquired several disquietening features which would surprise any osteopath, ear, nose and throat specialist or proctologist. Not that there seemed to be anybody (indeed, any body) else in the place, although once he caught what seemed to be a flash of motion in the sky. He squinted up into the grey light - the shapes that had sped by looked more like fish than birds; he must have been dreaming. That thought made him laugh.

He wandered over to one of the boulders, with the vague intention of climbing up it and looking for something - anything - on the horizon. The surface caught his eyes; like granite it was composed of a myriad tiny facets of crystal, white, orange, black, grey. Unlike granite some of these were quite large, and faintly grooved. These bigger lumps were uniformly white, and they puzzled him. It wasn't until he came across one that was protruding from the rest of the rock, pure white with a blunt point, that he twigged.

Teeth. The rocks were granite, he was sure of that from the mica, feldspar and quartz he recognised - any Dartmoor bog trotter knew granite as the city dwellers recognised concrete - but with an uneven sprinkling of teeth stirred in, like peanuts in a chocolate bar. Again, he thought of the Weasel's constant invectives against refined sugar when he was young; again reminded himself that somewhere his real body was supine and slightly more gummy.

But granite couldn't have teeth in it. Long-distant school geography lessons sprang to mind. Born of elementary fire, hot lava from the earth's core slowly cooling under tremendous pressure with crystals of hard rock forming over centuries, any organic matter would be fried, powdered and assimilated in minutes. It was, he reminded himself, a dream. One which would offend doctors, geologists and dentists in equal measure, but still a dream.

It had to have something to do with being in just such a dream, he thought, but he felt curiously elated. He felt plain curious too - he was looking forward to the next discovery, the next fact to fall out of this strange place. Again, he felt a little disquiet about the ease with which he'd forgotten about his real status as an office worker in Plymouth, but then that place had its fair share of grey skies and boredom too.

He hunted around in the grass until he found a small lump of rock. Odd - he looked around, the scattering of the stuff was fairly even as far as he could see - what on earth (or wherever, he reminded himself) could have caused this place to be like this. He imagined great glaciers slowly melting, dropping rocks as they retreated down the vast gouge they in earlier youth had carved, but that wouldn't explain the flatness of the place. Glaciated valleys - once more, those geography lessons with Rolly Jones surfaced after a decade submerged - were U-shaped. This was plain plane.

This blue and hairy body must belong to a blue and hairy geologist, he thought. He raised the rock above his head, and brought it down hard on the large boulder he'd been examining. The shock jarred his hand, but cracked off a small amount of the boulder's surface. He looked at the spray of chips that littered the grass. They were sharp, like flakes from the surface of a choc ice. The image of an ice cream, he couldn't remember the name, with small fragments of nut in the hard chocolate layer around the soft cream inside, came to mind, and on a whim he nibbled at one of the chips with his recently-enlarged canines. It tasted like a rock.

He looked at the place on the boulder where the chips came from, expecting to see more of the same, perhaps a little more colourful and sharp. Instead he saw a smooth skin, black as the night, underneath what must have just been a shell of toothed rock. He prodded it with one ridiculously long finger (without a fingernail; for a moment he couldn't decide whether it was sillier to have a finger without a fingernail or one with - why did humans have fingernails anyway? He resolved to find out when he was back in the real- he nearly thought other - world) and it gave way a little, like the skin on a dead pig.

Down at his feet, he found a particularly long shard of rock skin. With a roar he jabbed it into the gap on the boulder as hard as he could. This was, he discovered, very hard, and the skin broke. A gush of cold brown liquid shot out and over his - his? - body. He stood there for a moment, surprised, as the sticky coolness trickled down, matting the fine hair which covered him. He poked the same finger into the new gash, expecting to find a void. Instead he encountered a soft, sludgy gunk. It was very cold.

He pulled his finger out (for some reason, an image of his boss came to mind) startled by the unexpected feelings. Again on an impulse, he licked the finger. Chocolate ice cream. He pulled at the rock shell around the gap, removing scabs of the stuff and widening the hole until he could get a fist in. One part of his mind stood back, aghast, as a feeding frenzy took over and he pulled, tugged, hit at the shell, reducing it to fragments and revealing an interior entirely composed of ice cream. With a whoop, he started to scoop the stuff into his mouth, not minding whether it ran down his chin, onto his chest, caking him with stickyness.

"No. Chocolate. No chocolate. Bad for the teeth"

Eh? Where did the voice come from? He looked up, and realised that he was cold, shivering, and standing in a spreading puddle of molten ice cream. He was very, very messy.

"It'll ruin your teeth. Not good at all".

Was that - that was the Weasel. "Steve, you mustn't eat so much chocolate. Steve, you have to wake up to the fact that your teeth must last you the rest of your life. Steve, wake up. Steve!"

He shook his head, and suddenly felt very cold indeed. The grey of the sky lightened to orange, to white and he shivered.

"Steve, wake up!"

He blinked, and felt the ground somersault like a funfair ride. He tumbled, was lying down. He was on the couch, looking up at Dr Sells.

"Steve, can you hear me?"

"Uh" why was his mouth so horrible? "yeah. Yes, I can hear you. I've been dreaming, I think"

"Don't talk. Take deep breaths. Do you feel OK?"

Stupid dentist. How can I tell you if I can't talk? "Uhuh".

"Good. I hit an artery, though what it was doing there I don't know, and we had a bit of an emergnecy. You're OK, though, not too much blood lost, and I've called an ambulance just in case. Ruined your clothes though - I'm sorry."

His head spun. He tried to sit up, and in the couple of seconds before he collapsed back to the Chair he saw a blood-soaked body. At least it had pink hands.

Chapter 4

The doctors at Freedom Fields Hospital weren't concerned with his dream. "Happens all the time, old man" one particularly young one said "You're dreaming about walking through a town when a fire engine goes past, bell ringing like billy-oh. You wake up, and the alarm clock's going nineteen to the dozen. Brain's made the connection, you see."

Apart from the fact that he'd never owned an alarm clock with a bell, and suspected that the doctor had been watching too many Sunday afternoon wartime films, Steve saw. It had been a particularly vivid dream, but perhaps everyone dreamed like that under gas. He'd been given two pints of blood, which gave the lie to Dr Sells' soothing words, and was under observation for the rest of the day. According to the ward sister, he'd be out by seven since they needed the bed and he was young enough to survive "seeing what you young people do to yourselves nothing like this should worry you" by himself.

The tooth had been removed, and in its place was a lump of surgical padding. Steve explored it with his tongue, it seemed much large and ten times rougher than the tooth it replaced but he expected that was just the unfamiliarity and weirdness of the pad. Again he felt strange, he wasn't used to such ideas and didn't know where they came from. That they might come from himself seemed impossible.

The young doctor came back. "How are we doing?" "I'm feeling OK." He took Steve's blood pressure and pulse rate. "I think you'll be OK for this evening, but take it easy for the next week or so".

"Er, Doctor?"

"Yes?"

"I'm still worried by the dream I had."

The doctor sat down on the bed, and carefully placed his clipboard on the sheets before looking, seriously and with obvious intent, at Steve.

"We all have dreams, old man."

"No, I don't get dreams, apart from this time. It was so real, like being there, only I've never been anywhere like that before. Do you think it could have been the gas?"

"That's possible. It's really nothing to worry about, though. It's been quite a traumatic experience for you. Look, if the dreams come back or you're still worried about things a week from now I can recommend a friend of mine who should sort you out."

"He's a doctor too?"

"Yes, but not a blood and guts man like me. He's a psychoanalyst."

"Um... thanks. I think."

The doctor laughed "Nobody's saying you're anything but sane. It's just if you're troubled by this thing I don't know anyone better. He's especially good on dreams. Wrote a book about them a while back, I think he's quite famous."

"Among shrinks."

"Yes, I suppose. Look, hold on a minute."

The doctor scribbled out a name and phone number on his pad, and tore off the sheet. "Here you go. If you do give him a call, tell him Dr Chapman sent you, OK?"

"Thanks, mate. I hope I don't, if you see what I mean."

"Right. Anything else?" And as there was nothing else, the doctor left.

He caught the bus home. Experimentally probing the top of the wadding, he decided that soup and stuff would be on the menu for the next week. That night he slept soundly, for the last time, as the day's happenings were sorted and stored. For later.

In Chapter 4, Steve discusses his vivid dream with a young doctor while in the hospital, recovering from an unexpected dental surgery complication. Despite the doctor's reassurances that dreams are normal and not to be worried about, Steve is concerned about his unique experience. The doctor eventually gives Steve the contact information for a psychoanalyst specializing in dreams. Steve hopes that he won't need to call the psychoanalyst but appreciates the option. The chapter ends with Steve going home and recovering, seemingly unaware that Emily's diabolic plan has moved forward during his sleep.

conversation.content: Please summarise the content of these five papers in 1000 words, including six aspects: background, problem, methodology, analysis, case study and conclusion

Paper 1: "A Study on the Quality of Integration Framework for IOT in Automobiles"

Background: The integration of Internet of Things (IoT) in automobiles is becoming essential as the industry is shifting towards connected cars, autonomous vehicles, and smart transportation systems. Hence, there is a need to develop a framework to analyze and improve the quality of IoT integration in the automotive sector.

Problem: The major challenges in IoT integration in automobiles are the complexity of the integration process, security threats, privacy concerns, and compatibility issues. The lack of a standardized IoT integration framework leads to uncertainties in meeting customer demands, market competition, and efficient time-to-market strategies.

Methodology: A comprehensive review of the existing literature is conducted to identify various IoT integration strategies in automobiles. Based on the review, an IoT integration framework is proposed, and the framework's quality attributes such as reliability, manageability, security, and privacy are analyzed.

Analysis: Factors affecting the quality of IoT integration are identified, and their impact on the framework's quality attributes is assessed. A detailed analysis of the challenges and complexities of the integration process is presented, along with current solutions to address these challenges.

Case Study: A case study is conducted on a real-world automobile IoT integration scenario to validate the effectiveness of the proposed framework. The case study focuses on the integration of IoT devices, the communication network, and the IoT platform for an intelligent transportation system.

Conclusion: The proposed IoT integration framework for automobiles aims to provide a systematic and standard approach to improve the quality of IoT integration in the industry. This framework can be applied as a guideline for developers, service providers, and researchers in the automobile and IoT sectors. The case study validates the usability and effectiveness of the framework.

Paper 2: "Exploring Urban Sensing: A Toolkit for Participatory Sensing Applications"

Background: Urban sensing involves the use of sensors and other technologies to collect data from urban environments, enabling the development of smart cities and informed urban planning. Participatory sensing involves engaging communities in data collection through individual devices, such as smartphones or wearables.

Problem: There is a lack of accessible tools and frameworks for creating participatory sensing applications, and limited understanding of how these tools can be applied to different scenarios, locations, and communities.

Methodology: A toolkit for participatory sensing applications is developed, based on open-source software components and a visual programming interface. The toolkit is evaluated through a series of workshops with diverse participants, including researchers, designers, and residents.

Analysis: The toolkit’s usability, flexibility, and potential for supporting a variety of participatory sensing applications were assessed. Feedback from workshop participants was analyzed to identify issues and gather insights into the toolkit’s applicability in real-world scenarios.

Case Study: The participatory sensing toolkit is applied to a range of real-world settings, including air quality monitoring in a city, bike route mapping, and wildlife conservation. These case studies provide insights into the toolkit’s effectiveness in tackling different urban sensing challenges.

Conclusion: The developed toolkit for participatory sensing applications enables non-specialists to create and deploy urban sensing solutions more easily. The case studies demonstrate the toolkit’s potential for empowering communities in tackling local challenges, supporting decision-making and urban planning processes.

Paper 3: "Deep Learning-Based Sentiment Analysis on Twitter Data Revealing Public Opinion Trends"

Background: Social media platforms such as Twitter facilitate the real-time exchange of opinions and emotions. Analyzing sentiment from social media data can reveal public opinion trends, which can be valuable in fields like marketing, politics, and social sciences.

Problem: Traditional techniques for sentiment analysis involve manual annotation and rule-based methods, which are time-consuming and have limited accuracy. Deep learning approaches show promise but require large annotated datasets for training.

Methodology: A deep learning-based methodology is proposed, using convolutional neural networks (CNN) and long short-term memory (LSTM) networks for sentiment analysis on Twitter data. The method involves preprocessing raw data, feature extraction, CNN and LSTM algorithm implementation, and model evaluation.

Analysis: The performance of the proposed methodology is compared to traditional methods, such as Naïve Bayes and Support Vector Machines (SVM). Accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score are used as evaluation metrics to assess the effectiveness of the deep learning approach in sentiment analysis.

Case Study: A case study is conducted on a large dataset of Twitter data, focusing on the analysis of public opinion on a national event. The results reveal insights into public sentiment trends around the event, highlighting the potential of deep learning-based sentiment analysis in understanding social phenomena.

Conclusion: The proposed deep learning-based methodology outperforms traditional methods in sentiment analysis on Twitter data, indicating its potential to uncover valuable insights into public opinion trends. The case study demonstrates the applicability of this approach in real-world situations.

Paper 4: "Energy-aware Optimization of Computation Offloading in Mobile Cloud Computing"

Background: Mobile cloud computing enables the offloading of computation-intensive tasks from mobile devices to cloud servers, improving the device’s performance and energy efficiency. However, there is a need to optimize offloading strategies to minimize energy consumption while maintaining acceptable Quality of Service (QoS).

Problem: Existing offloading strategies often focus on the device's energy savings, neglecting the energy cost of communication between the device and the cloud server. This can lead to suboptimal performance and increased energy consumption.

Methodology: A two-stage energy-aware optimization framework is proposed for computation offloading in mobile cloud computing. The framework involves identifying candidate tasks for offloading, and then determining optimal offloading strategies based on energy consumption, communication latency, and computing resource availability.

conversation.content: Can you tell me about Kurt Lewin's main contributions, either as a theoretical construct or as a practical influence?

Kurt Lewin (1890 - 1947) was a German-American psychologist who is widely recognized as one of the pioneers of social psychology and organizational development. His main contributions include the development of various theoretical constructs and practical influences in the field of psychology and organizational studies, such as:

1. Field Theory: Lewin's most significant contribution is the development of field theory, which suggests that human behavior must be understood in the context of an individual's environment, both psychological and social. Field theory emphasizes the importance of considering the whole situation and interactions between individuals and their environments in understanding behavior. 

2. Force Field Analysis: Building on field theory, Lewin developed the concept of force field analysis, a method of analyzing the factors (forces) that influence a situation or decision, including supporting and opposing forces. This technique has been widely used in organizational change management and problem-solving, as it enables decision-makers to visualize the dynamics of a given situation, identify and assess different factors, and develop action plans accordingly.

3. Action Research: Lewin introduced the concept of action research, which is a problem-solving approach that involves a cyclical process of diagnosing, planning, implementing, and evaluating interventions to improve a specific situation, often in organizational contexts. Action research promotes collective learning, collaboration, and democratic decision-making and has been adopted in various fields such as education, social work, and management.

4. Group Dynamics: Lewin's work on group dynamics has been influential in understanding how individuals behave within groups and how group behaviors and processes can impact individual actions, motivation, and decision-making. His study about how different leadership styles (authoritarian, democratic, and laissez-faire) impact group performance and satisfaction has been significant for leadership and management theories.

5. Change Management: Lewin's change management model, also known as the 'unfreeze-change-refreeze' model or Lewin's three-step model, proposes a structured approach to managing organizational change by breaking it down into three distinct phases. The model suggests that to facilitate change effectively, one must first 'unfreeze' old habits and processes, then make the necessary changes, and finally 'refreeze' the new processes and habits in place. This model has been widely used in organizational change management and has influenced several change management theories.

6. Social Experiments: Lewin was also known for his experimental approach to social psychology, examining situations such as conformity, group pressure, and social facilitation. His innovative experimental methods and focus on real-world situations had a significant impact on the development of social psychology as a discipline.

Overall, Kurt Lewin's work has had a lasting impact on various aspects of psychology, organizational development, and change management. His theories, concepts, and methods continue to be applied and extended by researchers, practitioners, and organizations worldwide.

What sections should I include in a literature review?

The sections included in a literature review will depend on the topic of the review and the requirements of the assignment or publication. However, here is a general outline of the sections you could include in a literature review:

1. Introduction: The introduction should provide the research focus and rationale for the review. It should also specify the scope of the review, the research questions, and the keywords or concepts that guide the search.

2. Search strategy: The search strategy should detail the databases and search terms used to obtain the literature used in the review. This section may also include a description of the inclusion and exclusion criteria used to select articles for the review.

3. Literature selection: This section details the criteria used to select articles for the literature review. For instance, inclusion or exclusion criteria such as year range, country, type of literature or research design could be included here.

4. Critical evaluation: The critical evaluation section aims to evaluate the quality of the literature reviewed. This section can assess the relevance, reliability, and validity of the articles included.

浅度烘焙：一般在165℃左右进行，烘焙时间为10-12分钟。这样烘焙后咖啡豆有着浓郁的香气和清爽的酸度，口感中具有非常明显的果酸味，苦涩和甜味都比较轻。

中度烘焙：一般在190℃左右进行，烘焙时间为12-14分钟。烘焙后咖啡豆具有了较为明显的香气和口感，口感的酸度也比浅度烘焙略为厚重一些，同时咖啡的甜味和苦涩均比较平衡。

深度烘焙：一般在210℃左右进行，烘焙时间为15-18分钟。烘焙后咖啡豆具有非常浓烈的香气和口感，口感中的甜味开始变得越来越难以辨别，苦涩和重口味味道逐渐占据了口中的优势，适合加入牛奶和糖等调味。

总的来说，烘焙是影响咖啡豆风味和口感的一个非常重要的步骤。通过控制烘焙温度和时间，可以制作出不同风格的咖啡豆供消费者品尝和选择。不同的咖啡爱好者们有着不同的口味喜好，烘焙师们需要通过反复试验和探索，来制作出最适合不同口味人群的咖啡豆。

Ladies and gentlemen, esteemed colleagues and distinguished guests, welcome to today's Global Politics HL presentation. I will begin my presentation with a thought-provoking quote by the Dalai Lama: "Love and compassion are necessities, not luxuries. Without them, humanity cannot survive." Now, let us consider a situation that is severely lacking in love and compassion: the ongoing Rohingya crisis in Myanmar. Today, I will delve deep into the nuances of this crisis and explore its impact and significance in the realm of global politics.

To fully grasp the complexity of this situation, we must first define some critical concepts:
- Ethnic Conflict: A conflict between different ethnic groups that arises from differences in language, culture, religion, or other factors.
- Persecution: The systematic mistreatment of an individual or group on the basis of their race, religion, ethnicity, political beliefs, or other factors.
- Human Rights: Fundamental rights and freedoms that are inherent to all human beings, regardless of their status.
- State Sovereignty: The principle that each state has the right to govern itself without interference from other states.
- Nationalism: A political ideology that emphasizes the importance of the nation and the promotion of its interests.
- International Community: The group of states, organizations, and individuals that work together to address global issues and promote international cooperation.

Now, let us examine the Rohingya crisis in Myanmar. The Rohingya population, a Muslim minority group in predominantly Buddhist Myanmar, has faced a long history of persecution and marginalization. The Myanmar government denies the Rohingya citizenship, rendering them stateless and vulnerable. Over the past few years, violent crackdowns by the military have forced hundreds of thousands of Rohingya to flee Myanmar, resulting in a mass exodus and humanitarian crisis.

Several causes have culminated in the present crisis, including historical tensions between the Rohingya and the Buddhist majority, the Myanmar government's refusal to grant citizenship, and nationalist rhetoric aimed at vilifying and ostracizing the Rohingya. State sovereignty and nationalism both play significant roles in perpetuating this crisis, as the Myanmar government resists intervention and prioritizes its national interests over human rights.

The Rohingya crisis has had devastating social, political, and economic consequences, not just for the Rohingya population, but also for neighboring countries and the international community. The mass displacement has led to overcrowded refugee camps in neighboring countries such as Bangladesh, exacerbating poverty and increasing the risk of radicalization. Additionally, the crisis has strained relations between Myanmar and other countries, and it has drawn criticism and concern from international organizations such as the United Nations.

The international community's response to the crisis has been varied, with some states imposing sanctions and calling for accountability, while others prioritize diplomacy and humanitarian aid. Despite these efforts, it remains evident that the crisis has yet to be effectively and sustainably addressed.

In reflecting on the broader implications of the Rohingya crisis in global politics, we must not forget the serious issues it raises related to ethnic conflict, state sovereignty, and the protection of human rights. We must also recognize that, sadly, this is not an isolated event. Many other instances of persecution and conflict are taking place worldwide, affecting millions of people. As we look to the future, it is crucial for the international community to work together and prioritize human rights to prevent crises like the Rohingyas from happening repeatedly.

In conclusion, the Rohingya crisis is a stark reminder that humanity must strive to practice love and compassion in the face of adversity. It is our responsibility to protect the most vulnerable and work towards a world where every individual's rights are respected, and love and compassion truly become necessities. Thank you.

1. Introduction

"More than half a million lives wrecked, countless dead, mutilated, or raped, and more than a quarter of a million displaced, with no end in sight" (The Guardian, 2017). This chilling description illustrates the magnitude of the Rohingya crisis in Myanmar, a humanitarian catastrophe that has profound implications for global politics. With over 1 million people affected and an urgent need for a viable solution, the crisis raises critical questions about human rights, state sovereignty, and national identity.

2. Definition of Major Concepts

Before delving into the complexities of the Rohingya crisis, it is crucial to define some key terms: 

- Ethnic conflict: A conflict between two or more ethnic groups, often involving violence and discrimination.
- Persecution: The systematic and targeted mistreatment of a specific group of people, often due to their race, religion, or nationality.
- Human rights: The fundamental rights and freedoms to which all individuals are entitled, regardless of nationality, race, gender, or religious belief.

These concepts are central to understanding the underlying causes of the Rohingya crisis and the broader implications for global politics.

3. Case Study: The Rohingya Crisis in Myanmar

The Rohingya crisis traces back to the colonial era when British rulers encouraged the migration of Muslims from the Bengal region to work in Myanmar, then known as Burma. Over time, tensions between the Rohingya Muslims and Rakhine Buddhists in Myanmar intensified, leading to instances of sectarian violence. The denial of citizenship to Rohingya Muslims in 1982 further exacerbated the situation. 

The current crisis, however, began in 2016-2017 when Myanmar's military conducted a brutal crackdown on the Rohingya population. This has led to the displacement of over 700,000 individuals to neighboring Bangladesh, with countless cases of death, rape, and torture. 

The crisis not only has devastating consequences for the Rohingya people but also poses immense challenges for the Myanmar government, neighboring states, and the international community, as refugee camps and resettlement programs struggle to meet the escalating demand for aid and assistance.

4. Causes of the Rohingya Crisis

Numerous factors contribute to the Rohingya crisis, including historical, political, and economic circumstances. Key causes of the crisis include:

- Discrimination against Rohingya Muslims, rooted in religious and ethnic tensions.
- Statelessness: Rohingya Muslims are denied citizenship and access to basic rights, perpetuating a cycle of marginalization.
- Political motivations: Myanmar's government and military exploit the crisis to consolidate power and maintain control.

Global politics concepts such as state sovereignty, nationalism, and human rights play significant roles in perpetuating the crisis, as the Myanmar government seeks to maintain control over its territory and population while disregarding the rights of the Rohingya people.

5. Impacts of the Rohingya Crisis

The impacts of the Rohingya crisis are immense, affecting not only the Rohingya population but also neighboring countries and the international community. Consequences include:

- Unprecedented levels of displacement, with over 700,000 Rohingya refugees fleeing to Bangladesh.
- Strains on host countries as they struggle to accommodate the influx of refugees.
- Increasing poverty and destitution among displaced Rohingya populations.
- Heightened security threats, as the crisis fuels the risk of radicalization and terrorism.

Various actors are involved in addressing the crisis, such as the Myanmar government, neighboring countries, and international organizations. Each grapples with unique challenges and responsibilities, underscoring the intricate connections between local and global politics.

6. Reactions to the Rohingya Crisis

Responses to the crisis have been diverse, ranging from condemnation and diplomacy to direct intervention. Actors involved include states, NGOs, and international organizations, each adopting different strategies to contribute to a resolution:

- Condemnation and advocacy from governments, NGOs, and celebrities, calling for an end to the persecution of the Rohingya people.
- Diplomatic efforts by countries such as China and India, aiming to defuse tensions between Myanmar and Bangladesh.
- Humanitarian assistance provided by international organizations such as UNHCR and the World Food Programme.

While some progress has been made, many challenges persist, highlighting the difficulties faced by the international community in addressing this complex crisis.

7. Reflection

The Rohingya crisis is a stark reminder of the devastating effects of ethnic conflict and persecution on minority populations. By examining this case study in the context of global politics, we gain a deeper understanding of the factors that contribute to such crises and, potentially, the means to prevent them in the future.

As we reflect on the future outlook of the Rohingya crisis, it is important to consider the broader implications for global politics. Recognizing the complex interplay between local and international politics, we can begin to foresee potential actions that could alleviate the suffering of the Rohingya people and address the root causes of this ongoing tragedy. In conclusion, the Rohingya crisis is a critical reminder of the need for continued vigilance and commitment to the protection of human rights, respect for state sovereignty, and the pursuit of lasting peace in the global community.

Ladies and gentlemen, good evening. I would like to begin with a quote from Elie Wiesel, a Holocaust survivor and Nobel Laureate: "There may be times when we are powerless to prevent injustice, but there must never be a time when we fail to protest." Today, I will discuss a political issue that affects global politics: the Rohingya crisis in Myanmar. This issue not only matters to us in our everyday lives, but it also raises concerns about human rights, democracy, and international cooperation. 

Before I begin, let's define three important concepts in understanding the Rohingya crisis: ethnic conflict, persecution, and human rights. Ethnic conflict is a struggle between different ethnic or cultural groups, often stemming from historical, political, or economic issues. Persecution is the unfair treatment or hostility towards individuals based on their identity, while human rights are the basic rights and freedoms that every individual should have. These concepts are crucial for understanding the crisis and its implications on the Rohingyas, Myanmar, and the world.

Now, let's delve into the case study: the Rohingya crisis in Myanmar. The Rohingyas are a predominantly Muslim ethnic minority in Myanmar, a predominantly Buddhist country. Originally from the Rakhine state, they have faced discrimination and persecution for decades. In 2017, violence escalated when the Myanmar military launched an operation in response to insurgent attacks. As a result, more than 740,000 Rohingyas fled to Bangladesh, joining hundreds of thousands already there in refugee camps. The UN has described this as "a textbook example of ethnic cleansing" with reports of killings, rape, and burning of villages.

This crisis has significant consequences for the Rohingyas, the neighboring countries, and the international community. The Rohingyas face immense suffering, with many losing their lives and families being torn apart. Neighboring countries, particularly Bangladesh, bear the burden of hosting large Rohingya refugee populations. The international community faces a humanitarian crisis and the challenge of finding a durable solution to the situation.

So, what are the root causes of the Rohingya crisis? Historical factors include British colonial rule which brought Rohingyas to Myanmar as laborers, leading to hostility from Burmese nationalists. Post-independence, the Rohingyas were denied citizenship and considered illegal immigrants, which contributed to their marginalization. Politically, the Myanmar government has propagated narratives of Rohingyas being a threat to national security, while the Buddhist majority population views them as intruders with an incompatible culture. These factors tie into global politics concepts: state sovereignty, nationalism, and human rights, which all play significant roles in the crisis.

The impacts of the Rohingya crisis are far-reaching. For the Rohingyas, the persecution, displacement, and suffering impacts every aspect of their lives, including their social, political, and economic well-being. Neighboring countries must accommodate the influx of refugees and address the socio-economic costs of hosting them. The international community struggles to respond effectively, as the crisis creates tensions and divides internationalorganizations such as ASEAN and the UN.

The broader global community has reacted differently to the Rohingya crisis. Some states, such as Turkey and Saudi Arabia, have provided humanitarian aid and condemned the Myanmar government, while others, such as China, have emphasized non-interference in Myanmar's internal affairs. Several NGOs and international organizations, such as the UNHCR and Amnesty International, have been actively involved in providing aid and advocating for Rohingya rights. The approaches taken by the international community to address the crisis vary from humanitarian efforts, diplomatic pressure, and sanctions against Myanmar. However, these efforts have had limited success thus far, with the Myanmar government showing little willingness to cooperate or address root causes.

Reflecting on the Rohingya crisis within the larger context of global politics provides invaluable insights. It compels us to confront other instances of ethnic conflict and persecution of minority groups, such as the Uighurs in China or the Yazidis in Iraq. The crisis also highlights the difficulty of reconciling state sovereignty with moral and humanitarian concerns, as well as the complexities in multilateral diplomacy and international cooperation.

As we look to the future, much can still be done to address the Rohingya crisis. Solutions may include international mediation to establish a framework for repatriation, pressure on the Myanmar government to grant citizenship and equal rights to the Rohingyas, and continued humanitarian support for the refugees. It is crucial to keep this crisis on the global political agenda and learn from it, so that we may work towards a world where human rights are respected, and ethnic tensions are resolved peacefully.

In conclusion, the Rohingya crisis is a political issue that demands our attention and calls for a stronger international response. It exemplifies the challenges and complexities of global politics in addressing ethnic conflicts, state actions, and human rights. Let us remember the words of Elie Wiesel, and not remain silent in the face of injustice. Thank you for your attention.

Title: The Thailand Cave Rescue: Effects on Society and Worldwide Solidarity

Introduction:

The Thailand Cave Rescue operation, which occurred in July 2018, captivated the attention of people worldwide. The harrowing incident involved the Wild Boars, a junior football team, and their coach who were trapped in the Tham Luang Nang Non cave in Northern Thailand due to unexpected flooding. The ensuing 18-day complex and arduous rescue operation, which involved both Thai and international assistance, resulted in the successful extraction of all 13 members. This event not only brought out the spirit of brotherhood and solidarity but also highlighted prevailing societal issues which affected public perception and response to the rescue operation.

Global Response and Solidarity:

The Thailand Cave Rescue drew global attention and concern, as people from various walks of life united to offer their skills, resources, and prayers in support. The military, elite divers, and cave experts from multiple countries, including the USA, the UK, and Australia, worked tirelessly with the Thai counterparts to navigate the challenging logistics of the rescue. The global coming-together exemplified the inherent sense of empathy and connection amongst human beings in times of crisis.

The response from technology entrepreneurs and innovators was another noteworthy aspect of the rescue. Elon Musk, the well-known CEO of Tesla and SpaceX, offered a mini-submarine designed by SpaceX and Boring Company engineers to assist in the rescue. Although this submarine was not used in the actual operation, the gesture of support showcases the proactive attitude of the tech industry in addressing real-world problems.

Awareness and Preparedness for Future Incidents:

The Thailand Cave Rescue reiterated the importance of preparedness in dealing with unexpected adversities. Post this event, there has been a heightened focus on establishing effective training and resources to manage and mitigate similar scenarios in the future. Both local and international organizations are now developing proper protocols, guidelines, and imparting knowledge to the public, especially those who engage in adventure sports, on the best practices in times of emergencies.

Highlighting Prevalent Issues:

This incident also highlighted some of the socio-economic, environmental, and mental health issues prevalent in society. For instance, the coach's predicament brought to light the plight of stateless individuals living in Thailand. Ekkapol Chantawong, who is originally from Myanmar, lost his family and was orphaned at a young age. His status as a stateless refugee rendered him with limited rights and opportunities in Thailand. However, the cave incident played a crucial role in saving him from this legal limbo, as he was granted Thai citizenship in August 2018. This situation created awareness and urged the public to address the plight of stateless individuals living in the region.

Psychological Aspects:

The mental strength and resilience of the boys and their coach, amidst the ordeal, were indeed commendable. They employed techniques like meditation, taught by the coach, to maintain composure in the face of adversity. This occurrence emphasizes the vital role of mental health and mindfulness in overcoming life's substantial challenges. It also underlines the importance of empowering youths with essential psychological tools and techniques to survive and thrive in difficult situations.

Conclusion:

The Thailand Cave Rescue presented an extraordinary instance of global solidarity, compassion, and cooperation. People from different countries, professions, and backgrounds united to save the lives of the trapped football team. The incident proactively ignited honest conversations about legal, mental, and psychological aspects of society. Furthermore, it underscored the importance of preparedness and resilience in the face of adversity. The Thailand Cave Rescue will forever remain a powerful reminder of humanity's triumph, fueled by empathy and collaboration.

The Cold War marked a period of intense rivalry between superpowers, with the United States and the Soviet Union emerging as the chief antagonists. Despite sharing a communist ideology and an alliance in the early years of the Cold War, China and Russia had significant differences in their approaches to international affairs and domestic policies. This essay will compare and contrast China and Russia during the Cold War, examining their geopolitical strategies, economic policies, and ideological differences.

One key difference between China and Russia was their geopolitical strategies. Russia, under the leadership of Nikita Khrushchev, sought to maintain a strong military presence and expand the Soviet sphere of influence. This was evident in the deployment of missiles in Cuba, the formation of the Warsaw Pact, and the suppression of uprisings in Hungary and Czechoslovakia. China, on the other hand, pursued a policy of non-alignment and territorial disputes with its neighbours. For instance, China established diplomatic relations with Pakistan, while Russia supported India. This highlighted China's desire to maintain its strategic autonomy and avoid unnecessary conflicts that might weaken its position in Asia.

Another important difference between China and Russia during the Cold War was their economic policies. Russia focused on industrialization and investing heavily in military technology. This led to a heavily regulated economy that was not conducive to innovation and growth. In contrast, China followed a more pragmatic approach of mixing elements of socialism with market-based reforms. This enabled China to harness its vast reserves of cheap labour and achieve remarkable economic growth. As a result, China became a rising economic powerhouse during the Cold War, while Russia struggled with inflation and economic stagnation.

Finally, there were significant ideological differences between China and Russia during the Cold War. China criticized Russia for its revisionist policies concerning the Chinese border, and for a perceived failure to uphold Marxist ideology. China favored a more radical and revolutionary brand of socialism, whereas Russia's communism was seen by China as bureaucratic, elitist, and compromised by reformism. Moreover, China saw itself as the ideological center of the global communist movement and believed that it could set an example for the developing world in the struggle against imperialism and colonialism.

In conclusion, China and Russia had different geopolitical strategies, economic policies, and ideological orientations during the Cold War. Despite sharing a common ideological framework, their experiences of communist rule were vastly different. Russia's approach was more militaristic and authoritarian, while China's was more pragmatic and reform-oriented. These fundamental differences were compounded by territorial disputes and a power struggle between the two countries for leadership of the global communist movement. Despite this, both China and Russia played vital roles in shaping the outcome of the Cold War and leaving a lasting legacy on the world order.

1. International Trade: After the end of the Cold War, the U.S. worked towards promoting a more integrated global trading system. The North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), signed in 1992, established a trade bloc between the U.S., Canada, and Mexico, committing to reduce trade barriers and improve economic cooperation. NAFTA facilitated increased trade among these three nations, with the U.S. being a driving force behind the agreement.

The establishment of the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 1995 also marked a significant moment in global trade relations. The WTO provided a global platform for negotiating trade agreements, establishing rules, and resolving disputes. The U.S. played a central role in its formation and, as a member, sought to shape international trade rules to reflect its economic interests and values.

2. Environmental Policy: U.S. engagement in international environmental policy evolved after the end of the Cold War. The Kyoto Protocol, adopted in 1997, marked a significant step in global efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and address climate change. However, the U.S. had varied stances on the Kyoto Protocol. Although it was instrumental in the negotiation process, the U.S. Senate did not ratify the agreement, citing concerns over economic competitiveness and the absence of commitments from developing countries like China and India. Consequently, the U.S. remained outside the Kyoto Protocol, hindering its full effectiveness.

3. Wars in Afghanistan and Iraq: In the wake of the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks, the U.S. launched military interventions in Afghanistan and Iraq. These interventions represented a new era of U.S. global engagement, in which the nation sought to combat terrorism, protect American interests, and promote democracy. The invasion of Afghanistan sought to topple the Taliban regime and eliminate Al-Qaeda's operational base. The Iraq War aimed to remove Saddam Hussein from power and prevent the alleged possession and use of weapons of mass destruction.

conversation.content: Hello, ChatGPT. Can you give me a list of all the main reasons why power transitions are important in democratic countries and why democracy should avoid having one president/ruling party for too lon?

Power transitions are an essential aspect of maintaining a healthy and vibrant democracy. Here are some of the main reasons why power transitions are important in democratic countries and why democracy should avoid having one president or ruling party for too long:

1. Preventing the concentration of power: Ensuring regular power transitions helps prevent the concentration of power in the hands of a single president or ruling party, which could potentially lead to autocracy or dictatorship.

2. Checks and balances: A power transition provides an opportunity for an incoming ruling party or president to evaluate and examine the policies and actions of the previous administration. This process helps identify inefficiencies and potential abuses of power and allows for the correction of any imbalances.

3. Representing diverse interests: In a democratic society, it is essential that various political perspectives and ideologies have an opportunity to participate in governance. Regular power transitions facilitate this representation, giving voice to different segments of the population.

4. Encouraging political innovation: A continual shift in leadership and ruling parties can generate new perspectives and policy ideas, fostering a culture of innovation and improvement in governance.

5. Reducing corruption: Entrenched power structures can often lead to increased corruption and cronyism. Power transitions work as a system of checks on such practices by holding leaders and their affiliates accountable for their actions.

6. Strengthening democratic institutions: Regular power transitions contribute to the development and strengthening of democratic institutions, as they demonstrate the resilience and openness of the political system.

7. Promoting political stability: Peaceful power transitions signal to citizens and the international community that a country's political system is stable and mature. This can help attract investment and maintain positive diplomatic relationships.

8. Responsiveness to the electorate: When governments know they can be voted out of power, they are more likely to remain responsive to the needs and demands of their citizens, leading to better governance and policy.

9. Renewed public trust in the political system: Power transitions help counter voter apathy and disillusionment by demonstrating that change is possible within the political system.

10. Adapting to societal changes: As societies evolve over time, it is important that their governments can also adapt and address modern-day challenges. Regular power transitions help ensure that governments remain relevant and on-track with societal changes.

Political Party: A political party is a group of individuals who come together with a common goal of winning elections and governing.

Functions of political parties: The primary functions of political parties are to nominate candidates for office, mobilize voters, formulate public policy, and govern at all levels of government.

Democratic Party: The Democratic Party is one of two major political parties in the United States. They are generally associated with progressive policies and a focus on social issues.

Republican Party: The Republican Party is one of two major political parties in the United States. They are generally associated with conservative policies and a focus on fiscal issues.

Dealignment and Third Parties: Dealignment refers to the trend of people shifting away from both major parties and becoming independent or joining third parties. Third parties are political parties that exist in addition to the two major parties. Examples of third parties include the Green Party, Libertarian Party, and Constitution Party.

Critical Elections and Realignment: Critical elections are elections that bring about a significant change in the political landscape. Realignment refers to the long-lasting change in the political alignment of voters that can result from a critical election. Examples of critical elections and realignments in the book include the elections of 1860, 1932, and 1968.

Winner-take-all System vs. Proportional Representation: The winner-take-all system is a voting system in which the candidate with the most votes wins the election. Proportional representation is a voting system in which several seats are allocated to candidates based on the proportion of the vote they receive. The United States uses a winner-take-all system, while many other countries use proportional representation.

Types of Third Parties: Third parties can be divided into several categories, including protest parties, single-issue parties, factions within major parties, and splinter parties.

Impact of Third Parties: Third parties can have a significant impact on elections and politics, even if they don't win. They can influence the debate, pull votes away from major party candidates, and act as a spoiler.

Political Machines and Patronage: Political machines were corrupt organizations that used bribes and patronage (the exchange of government jobs for political support) to maintain power in local politics. They were prevalent in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

Fifth Party System: Democratic Dominance 1932-1968: The Fifth Party System refers to the period of time from 1932 to 1968, during which the Democratic Party dominated national politics. Congress has the power to authorize fines against individuals or organizations for violating federal laws, but it generally does not have the power to directly issue fines to the bureaucracy. Rather, agencies and bureaucrats are subject to fines and penalties through the agencies' specific statutory and regulatory authority, as well as through court-imposed penalties resulting from legal action taken against those agencies by Congress or affected parties.

Congress can, however, indirectly influence agency behavior through the appropriations process by withholding agency funds or imposing budget restrictions if the agency fails to perform its duties or comply with certain requirements. Additionally, Congress can use its oversight powers to investigate agency activities and compel agency compliance with statutory requirements, and can hold agency officials accountable through the impeachment and removal process.
